Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research:The Role of Ecomorphodynamic Feedbacks in Barrier Island Response to Climate Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Climate-change-induced sea level rise and increases in storm intensity will affect barrier islands worldwide. The traditional view of barrier island evolution considers only changes in environmental conditions (such as sea level rise, changes in storms) and physical processes (such as the transport of sand), and predicts that barrier islands will respond to climate change gradually. However, recent work suggests that biological factors involving vegetation and interactions, or feedbacks, between vegetation and physical processes are also important in shaping islands and determining how they will respond to changing conditions in the future. For example, anticipated climate-change induced shifts in the geographic ranges of dune-building grasses may increase the vulnerability of islands to storms by changing the shape and height of protective dunes. And, just as interactions between vegetation and physical processes can build dunes (via sand trapping by dune-building grasses) they can also hinder, and even prevent, dune-building by maintaining areas of low elevation. Such feedbacks may cause gradual changes in environmental conditions to produce rapid changes in barrier island evolution, which would make human adaptation difficult. This project will allow us to better understand the processes that are important in determining how barrier islands will change in the future and the conditions under which the important processes and interactions will likely lead to rapid, rather than gradual changes in island behavior.

This project will test a hypothesis that ecomorphodynamic feedbacks have the potential to amplify the effects of climate change on barrier island evolution, causing a nonlinear response to gradual changes in forcing, i.e., tipping points at which barrier islands rapidly convert from a high-relief, stable, ecologically diverse state to a low-relief, rapidly migrating, ecologically homogenous state. Through integrated numerical modeling and ecological experiments in the undeveloped barrier system of the Virginia Coast Reserve (VCR) LTER this project will address critical questions including: How do vegetation and physical processes interact in the formation and evolution of barrier island topography? How do overwash events affect topographic recovery and colonization of vegetation following storms? What is the role of ecomorphodynamic feedbacks in topographic recovery following storms? What combinations of factors lead to tipping points in the transition between high-relief and low-relief states as a result of nonlinearities in the ecomorphodynamic system? How are ecomorphodynamic feedbacks altered by climate change and what is the role of feedbacks in the transition between states?

POR.DRECONTENT:
A better understanding of how barrier islands will respond to changing conditions, and the mechanisms driving future barrier island response, are prerequisites for the sustainable management of coastal resources and informed decision making on barrier island coastlines. Coastal foredunes—the line of seaward-most dunes—can reduce storm impacts by providing protection for infrastructure and habitats on their landward side.  This study has advanced our fundamental understanding of the feedbacks between sediment transport and dune vegetation that give rise to coastal dunes and has provided a new understanding regarding the role of coastal dunes in the evolution of barrier islands under changing conditions (e.g., rising sea level, increasing frequency of high water events and decreases in sediment supply).      

Work under this project has demonstrated that the maximum dune height that can be achieved naturally depends on the distance between the shoreline and the vegetation line.  Longer distances (i.e., a wider beach) allows dunes to grow taller before the dune topography interferes with the wind such that it prevents the transport of sand from the beach to the dune.  This means that building tall dunes naturally requires a wide beach, a result with implications for coastal management.  Model results, consistent with observations, indicate that the initial aeolian phase of dune growth is slow and that dune growth rate increases rapidly once vegetation becomes established.  This also has implications for coastal management practices in that bypassing the slow phase of dune growth by building a beach to the critical elevation for vegetation growth, may lead to more rapid growth of natural dunes following storms.  Rapid dune growth is especially important under conditions of rising sea level rise and/or increasing storm frequency.  As high water events, or storms, occur more frequently, there is the possibility for dunes (or barrier islands) to be bistable, meaning that both a high topographic state and a low topographic state are possible under the same conditions.  When dunes or islands are bistable, islands may rapidly change from a high to a low state (during storms) and vice versa (via dune growth), however, opposing feedbacks will tend to reinforce the high or low state until there is a sufficiently severe storm to convert a high dune to a low dune, or a sufficiently long gap between storms for a low dune to grow to become a high dune.  Further model experiments confirm that different dune grass species give rise to dunes of different shapes and that the tendency for dunes dominated by Uniola paniculata (versus Ammophila breviligulata) to be hummocky arises from the interplay between its slow lateral growth rate (which leads to a slower dune growth rate) and interruption of the dune-building process by storms. 

A large-scale dune grass experiment yielded the following additional insights that have relevance to coastal restoration and management:  1) planting dune grass at low elevations where they have access to groundwater allows for more rapid vegetation growth and therefore more rapid growth of natural dunes; 2) Spartina patens, although less stimulated by burial than Ammophia breviligulata and Uniola paniculata, grows more rapidly when it is buried by sand deposition than when not buried, and is thus better classified as a moderate dune builder than as a species that maintains low elevations, as previously thought; 3) the location of the vegetation line is determined by the cross-shore location where the number of days of inundation by high water is sufficient to remove or lead to the mortality of beach and dune vegetation. 

This project provided training for 2 graduate students, 2 postdoctoral associates and 3 undergraduate students at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.  This project has yielded two masters theses, 11 peer-reviewed journal papers, 2 book chapters and an edited volume published by Springer.  The results of this work have been presented in multiple venues, from national conferences held by the American Geophysical Union and the Geological Society of America to the Barrier Island Center on the Eastern Shore of VA, university audiences, an elementary school audience and to the American Shore and Beach Preservation Association Dunes Meeting, where academics, government researchers, practitioners, managers and government officials came together to discuss the state of coastal dune science and future needs in this area of research.  Results have also contributed to the basis for the development of a play script designed to communicate the impact of climate change on barrier islands.  As planned, the models developed under this project are open access and freely available via the Community Sediment Dynamics Modeling System (CSDMS), where a tutorial for the Coastal Dune Model, developed as part of this project, is also available for use by other researchers.  Data collected under this project is archived in the Virginia Coast Reserve-Long-term Ecological Research site data repository.
